articles.title: Amateur stargazer finds his 2nd comet
articles.summary: Amateur astronomer Donald Machholz has discovered his second comet, officially named Comet 1985e after him. This significant event in amateur astronomy is highlighted, with details on how to locate the comet being covered in the current month's ephemeris.

articles.title: ANNUAL CLUB PICNIC AND EVENING STAR PARTY AT GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK NOON TILL 7??
articles.summary: This document details an astronomy club's upcoming events for July and August, including the Annual Club Picnic and Evening Star Party at Grant Ranch County Park on July 20th. It also lists several other star parties at various locations like Yosemite and Fremont Peak, moon phase dates, and an indoor star party. A key highlight is Ernest W. Piini's presentation on the New Guinea Total Solar Eclipse scheduled for August 3rd.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: This article provides an update for the upcoming July 12/13 Glacier Point star party in Yosemite, detailing logistical information for attendees regarding entrance waivers, camping at Bridalveil, and power access. It offers practical advice for SJAA members on setting up telescopes for public viewing, emphasizing varied object selection, suitable eyepieces for children, and safety precautions. The update also mentions a formal program by the park service including a slide show.

articles.title: CLUB TELESCOPES
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) provides three telescopes for its members to borrow. The standard loan period is two months, with members arranging transfers between themselves. If there's no demand, members can keep the telescope longer, requiring only notification to a board member or bulletin editor when it changes hands.

articles.title: CONCERNING WANT ADS:
articles.summary: The article announces that all SJAA members and friends are invited to place free astronomy-related want ads in the "Ephemeris" publication. Each ad will run for two months unless otherwise specified, and submissions should be mailed to the provided address.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz recounts his experience comet hunting during the Riverside Telescope Maker's Conference in May 1985, utilizing his custom-built 10-inch reflecting telescope. He details his observation techniques, references his past discovery of Comet Machholz, and describes the detection of a suspicious fuzzy object during his 1585th comet hunting session.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz recounts his discovery of a new comet, detailing the careful observation process, the initial challenges in confirming its motion, and the arduous task of reporting it to the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory. Despite communication difficulties and time pressure, he, with help from others, eventually confirmed the comet's existence and motion. The article concludes with details about the comet's preliminary orbit and its visibility.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article, 'Comet Comments' by Don Machholz, reports on recent comet activity, including the discovery of Comet Shoemaker and the recovery of Periodic Comet Tauchinshan 2 (1985d), which remains very faint. It also notes Comet Giacobini-Zinner (1984e) brightening and Halley's Comet emerging from behind the sun, promising a look at its 1835 visit and upcoming positions.

articles.title: Comet Machholz (1985e): The first comet to be discovered this year was found by myself on the morning of May 12. I was comet hunting from the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference at a site in California. This find occurred 1724 search hours after my first comet discovery! Comet 1978t. My discovery comet 1985e was low in the eastern predawn sky, at Mag. 9.3.
articles.summary: The author announces their discovery of Comet Machholz (1985e) on May 12, marking their second comet find, made during a comet hunt at the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference. The comet was observed at magnitude 9.3 in the predawn sky. Preliminary orbital data indicates a very close perihelion passage on June 28, after which it is expected to appear in the evening sky in July before fading.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This article provides ephemerides for Comet Machholz (1985e) and Periodic Comet Giacobini-Zinner (1984e) for late June through July. It details Machholz's close approach to the sun and subsequent appearance in the evening sky, noting its rapid dimming and potential visibility in binoculars. For Giacobini-Zinner, the article describes its brightening in the morning sky and mentions the planned ISEE space probe encounter in September.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND--HALLEY'S
articles.summary: This article discusses past and present appearances of Halley's Comet. It details the comet's 1835 apparition, including its discovery, visibility, and orbital data. The article also provides current (at the time of writing) ephemeris data and observing tips for amateurs attempting to recover the comet as it emerges from behind the sun.

articles.title: COMET MACHHOLZ - 1985e
articles.summary: The article announces the recent discovery of Comet Machholz 1985e by Don Machholz, a member of the publishing association. It highlights the significance of his discovery and extends enthusiastic congratulations and praise to him from the organization.

articles.title: SOUTH PACIFIC COMET TRIP
articles.summary: Lee Bonneau from Foothill College is coordinating a 21-day "South Pacific Discovery" trip to Australia for optimal viewing of Halley's Comet in early spring 1985, as local visibility will be poor. The tour, centered around Alice Springs, is available for college credit and offers potential discounts for SJAA members willing to assist with telescopes or astrophotography.

articles.title: NEW TREASURER
articles.summary: Jack Peterson, a long-time member, has accepted the position of club Treasurer, replacing Bob Fingerhut. Fingerhut is transitioning to a full-time role as the club President. Peterson will collaborate closely with Fingerhut during the upcoming membership renewal period.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP RENEWAL
articles.summary: Many members have not yet paid their annual dues, with only about 50% having renewed. Members are urged to submit their renewals before the August cut-off date, after which non-renewing members will receive their final bulletin. Renewal payments should be sent to Jack Peterson or Bob Fingerhut, whose contact information is provided.

articles.title: ANNUAL ASSOCIATION PICNIC AND INSTALLATION OF OFFICERS
articles.summary: The SJAA is holding its annual picnic at Grant Ranch county park, starting at 12 p.m., with a star party following at dusk. Members can enjoy provided burgers and hot dogs, bring their own drinks and condiments, and witness the installation of new officers. Attendees are encouraged to bring telescopes for the evening star party.

articles.title: HOT TIME AT THE PEAK
articles.summary: A star party at Fremont Peak on the weekend of July 15th was significantly impacted by sweltering temperatures, reaching 90 degrees during the day and only dropping to 78 degrees at night. These extreme conditions resulted in poor transparency, poor seeing, and difficulties for astrophotography, making comfortable viewing challenging for attendees. Despite the heat, Bob Fingerhut utilized his 16-inch telescope for astrophotography.

articles.title: BAUMGARDT PHOTOGRAPHS ROCKETS
articles.summary: SJAA member Jim Baumgardt photographed a spectacular dual rocket launch witnessed by thousands at the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference. He sent his "fantastic" slides to Sky and Telescope, with the author expressing hope they will make the magazine's front cover.

articles.title: SJAA CONTRIBUTORS FOR ASTRONOMY MAGAZINE
articles.summary: Four members of the SJAA (San Jose Astronomical Association) have had their astrophotography featured in the July issue of Astronomy Magazine, marking a potential record for the organization. These contributing members—Jack Marling, Jim Baumgardt, Bob Fingrhut, and John Bleason—will be present at the Yosemite star party on July 13th and available to sign autographs.

articles.title: CLUB TELESCOPES
articles.summary: The club editor is requesting information regarding the current location of the club's 14-inch, 6-inch, and 12-inch telescopes. This information is needed so it can be published in the Ephemeris for members.

articles.title: BY: DAVID SCHRIEBERG
articles.summary: Amateur astronomer Donald Machholz discovered his second comet, officially labeled Comet Machholz (1985e), on May 27, 1985, after thousands of hours of sky scanning. Verified by the Central Bureau of Astronomical Telegrams, this discovery highlights the significant contributions amateurs make to astronomy. This new comet is considered more scientifically valuable than his first due to its rare close approach to the sun, which occurs only about once every five years.

articles.title: DISCOVERY MOVED TO LAUNCH PAD FOR 51-G LAUNCH
articles.summary: The Space Shuttle Discovery has been moved to the launch pad in preparation for its 51-G mission, scheduled for June 17. This mission will deploy communication satellites for Mexico, Saudi Arabia, and AT&T, along with several scientific experiments, including the Spartan high energy astrophysics experiment. The crew will include Payload Specialists Patrick Baudery from France and Prince Sultan Salman Abdel Aziz Al-Saud from Saudi Arabia.

articles.title: SPACELAB 2 SCHEDULED FOR JULY LAUNCH
articles.summary: The Spacelab 2 mission (51-F) is scheduled for launch on July 15 aboard the orbiter Challenger, equipped with the Spacelab Igloo and three pallets. Following this, the Spacelab D-1 mission (51-J) is planned for an October 16 launch using the orbiter Columbia.

articles.title: ATLANTIS TO GO TO THE PAD FOR FIRST TIME
articles.summary: The space shuttle orbiter Atlantis is preparing for its first mission, starting with its move to the launch pad in July after Mission 51-F. This will be followed by a 20-second engine firing test around July 31. Atlantis will then be removed for a fuel tank readiness mission in late August before returning to the pad for its inaugural flight in mid-September.

articles.title: SOVIETS LAUNCH SOYOUZ T-13 TO SALYUT-7
articles.summary: The Soviet Union has launched the Soyuz T-13 mission with two cosmonauts towards the Salyut-7 space station, which was previously believed to be abandoned. This mission is anticipated to be a long-duration repair effort for the orbiting station.

articles.title: ARIANE LAUNCHES 2 SATELLITES
articles.summary: An Ariane 3 launcher successfully orbited two communication satellites from Kourou, French Guiana, on May 7. The article also details several upcoming Ariane missions throughout 1985, including the launch of the ESA Giotto Halley's Comet flyby spacecraft, further communication satellite deployments, and scientific satellite launches.

articles.title: ARIANE 4 ENGINE TESTS CONDUCTED
articles.summary: Hot firing tests of the large liquid boosters for the Ariane 4 rocket were successfully conducted on April 24 and May 9. These UDMH and N2O4-fueled boosters will be strapped onto the core vehicle in either two or four units, depending on the specific payload lift capacity requirements.

articles.title: CONTROL OF NOAA-8 REGAINED
articles.summary: NOAA successfully regained control of the NOAA-8 weather satellite after its master clock crystal oscillator failed on April 20. Controllers were able to reprogram the satellite's computer using a backup oscillator and reorient it once the faulty unit completely stopped functioning.

articles.title: NASA RECONFIGURES VOYAGER 2 AND GROUND STATIONS FOR URANUS FLYBY
articles.summary: NASA is reconfiguring the Voyager 2 spacecraft and its Deep Space Network ground stations in preparation for its Uranus flyby on January 22, 1986. Due to the immense distance of 1.8 billion miles, the spacecraft will transmit data at a slower rate than previous flybys. Voyager 2 is also scheduled for a subsequent flyby of Neptune in August 1989.

articles.title: SPACE STATION PACTS SIGNED WITH JAPAN, CANADA, AND EUROPE
articles.summary: Agreements have been signed with Japan, Canada, and Europe to conduct Phase B studies for a space station. Japan plans to contribute a pressurized technology research laboratory module, while Canada will focus on versions of the space shuttle's manipulator arm. Europe is interested in supplying a fly-along module named Columbus, with the long-term goal of developing an all-European space station.

articles.title: SOVIET BOOSTER DEVELOPMENT PROBLEMS
articles.summary: The Soviet Union is experiencing difficulties in developing liquid fuel engines for its SL-X-16 booster, a 200 ft tall vehicle crucial for both heavy lift and the Soviet Shuttle program. This booster has seen repeated setup and removal from launch pads, indicating ongoing issues. Despite these booster challenges, the Soviet Shuttle program itself appears to be progressing, with two orbiter vehicles observed at the Ramenskoye Flight Test Center.

articles.title: PLANETARY NEBULAE IN HERCULES AND LYRA BY JACK MARLING
articles.summary: This article highlights that the constellations Hercules and Lyra, often underestimated by deep-sky observers, contain 15 planetary nebulae beyond the well-known M-13, M-92, and M-57. It introduces several obscure, faint (13-15th magnitude) planetaries like Abell 39 and Kohoutek 10-14, presenting them as challenging and novel observing targets since many were not observed before 1985.

articles.title: All 15 planetaries are listed in the table below.
articles.summary: This document presents a table listing 15 planetary nebulae with their 2000.0 coordinates, angular size, visual magnitude, and surface brightness. The data, compiled from professional literature and the Catalog of Named Planetary Nebulae, includes photometric flux measurements and a definition for surface brightness. This information is indicated as part of a larger book on approximately 500 planetaries currently in preparation.

articles.title: DESCRIPTION OF INDIVIDUAL OBJECTS
articles.summary: This document provides detailed observational notes on numerous individual planetary nebulae, including their discovery information, magnitudes, and visual characteristics. It frequently offers practical advice on observing these objects, emphasizing the crucial role of filters like UHC and Oxygen-III for improved visibility, and often includes personal observing experiences and challenges.

articles.title: CALICO OBSERVATORY BY:JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: The article presents two distinct topics: a cautionary letter from Stephen D. Greenberg regarding the discovery of radioactive uranium-containing glass in a surplus Erfle eyepiece, leading him to warn amateur astronomers about potential radiation exposure and eye damage from old optics. The second part is a report from Jim Van Nuland of Calico Observatory, providing an observing update and transit predictions for Jupiter's Great Red Spot, noting its faintness but offering tips for successful observation and requesting feedback from fellow enthusiasts.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The article provides a detailed report on the 17th Annual Riverside Telescope Makers Conference (RTMC), attended by 1000 astronomy enthusiasts. The author notes a prevalence of mechanically unstable telescopes and poor atmospheric seeing, while highlighting impressive custom builds like Bob Klein's 12" f/5 Newtonian and critically evaluating new products like Ed Byers' Model 58 mount. The event also featured speakers, a new observatory, and unexpected entertainment, with the author enjoying an extended stay despite observed equipment shortcomings.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document outlines the schedule and location for general meetings, which are held at 8:00 PM on the first Friday of each month at the Los Gatos Red Cross building. The location also hosts SJAA's "Indoor Star Parties" and provides detailed driving directions from Hwy. 17.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK:
articles.summary: Grant Ranch County Park is a popular observing site for the SJAA, located on Mt. Hamilton Road. The article provides detailed driving directions to the park, instructions for using the SJAA's combination lock (4565) on the front gate after sunset, and mentions an additional observing area further up the road. Attendees are reminded to lock the gate securely after entry and exit.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to Henry Coe State Park, accessible via Hwy 101 South and the East Dunne exit, including a map and specific instructions for navigating to an observing site. It outlines important access rules, such as the locked gate combination (4565), the necessity to re-lock the gate, and guidelines for arriving after dark, emphasizing safety and preparation.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park's Coulter Camp, a designated setup location for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It guides visitors from Hwy 101/156 to the specific camp location within the park and includes a crucial reminder to use parking lights only after dark.

articles.title: OFFICERS:
articles.summary: This document lists the current officers of an organization, including the President, Vice-President, Secretary, and Treasurer. For each officer, their name, title, mailing address, and phone number are provided.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
articles.summary: This document lists the names and phone numbers of individuals serving on the Board of Directors. It functions as a contact directory for the organization's leadership.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS EDITOR:
articles.summary: This document fragment introduces a topic titled "EPHEMERIS EDITOR" and provides the contact information for its author, John P. Gleason. No further details about the editor's functionality, purpose, or content are included in this excerpt.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines different membership tiers and their respective costs, including options for junior members and subscriptions to Sky & Telescope. The form requests personal contact information and includes an optional questionnaire about the applicant's astronomical interests and equipment.
